{{more citations needed|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Harmony Gold USA, Inc. | trading_name = Harmony Gold | logo = HarmonyGoldLogo.jpg | logo_size = 240px | type = [[Private company]] | foundation = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]] (1983) | location = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], [[United States|USA]] | key_people = {{plainlist| *Frank Agrama, [[Chairman]] *Jehan F. Agrama, [[President (corporate title)|President]] and [[CEO]] *Christy Pawlak, [[President (corporate title)|President]] and [[General Counsel]] *[[Tommy Yune]], President of animation *Steve Yun, webmaster}} | industry = [[Television program]]s | products = {{plainlist| * [[Film|Motion pictures]] * [[Television program]]s * [[Miniseries]] * [[Animation]] * [[Video game]]s * [[Real estate]]}} | num_employees = | revenue = | net_income = }} '''Harmony Gold''' is a [[real estate developer]], [[Film distribution|motion picture]] and [[Broadcast syndication|television]] distributor, and film, television, and animation [[production company]], video game developer and publisher, based in Los Angeles. It was founded in 1983 by [[Egypt]]ian-born [[Frank Agrama]] and is managed by his daughter, Jehan F. Agrama.
The company began by selling broadcast rights from [[Paramount Pictures]] to the [[Mediaset]] media conglomerate.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.afr.com/business/media-and-marketing/tv/how-bruce-gordon-the-man-from-win-helped-catch-silvio-berlusconi-20150302-13sqe2|title=How Bruce Gordon, the man from WIN, helped catch Silvio Berlusconi |accessdate=2015-08-12 |work= Australian Financial Review |publisher= |date= }}</ref> It is best known as the distributor of the controversial ''[[Shaka Zulu (TV series)|Shaka Zulu]]'' miniseries and for various [[anime]] series, notably ''[[Robotech (TV series)|Robotech]]''.
The company worked closely with Intersound, a Los Angeles-based [[Recording studio|post-production recording studio]], managed by Frank Agrama's son, Ahmed Agrama. They were responsible for partially dubbing ''[[Dragon Ball]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/anncast/2010-01-14 |title=Macek Training|accessdate=2010-01-25 |work= Anime News Network |publisher= |date= }}</ref> ''[[Magical Princess Minky Momo]]'' and ''[[Dr. Slump]]'' before going out of business in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.crystalacids.com/news/2006/07/13/379/|title=Robotech dubbing studio closing down|accessdate=2015-11-12 |work=Crystal Acids}}</ref>
In addition to its distribution and production interests, Harmony Gold manages several [[real estate]] properties in the Southern California area. They also operate a screening room in Los Angeles.
==History==
===Beginnings in late 1970s=== Harmony Gold's story began in the 1976, when [[Frank Agrama]] began selling broadcast rights from [[Paramount Pictures]] to his friend, former Italian Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi|Silvio Berlusconi's]] [[Mediaset]] media company. In the late 1970s, Agrama, while in a trade fair in [[Cannes]], [[France]], met [[Hong Kong]] [[entrepreneur]]s Paddy Chan Mei-yiu and Katherine Hsu May-chun. The three agreed to form a collaboration to trade movie rights internationally. Chan set up Hong Kong-based company Harmony Gold Limited in 1979, while Agrama set up Agrama Film Enterprises on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1324781/italian-prosecutors-say-hong-kong-women-were-key-massive-money|title=Italian prosecutors say Hong Kong women were key to a massive money-laundering scheme|publisher=South China Morning Post|date=22 May 2014}}</ref> In 1983, Agrama set up Harmony Gold. He later also became the Los Angeles commercial representative of another of Chan's companies, Wiltshire Trading.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1324781/italian-prosecutors-say-hong-kong-women-were-key-massive-money|title=Italian prosecutors say Hong Kong women were key to a massive money-laundering scheme|publisher=South China Morning Post|date=22 May 2014}}</ref>
===The 1980s: notable projects===
====''Shaka Zulu'' (1983–1986)==== In late 1983, Agrama negotiated a deal with the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation]] (SABC) to distribute the controversial ''[[Shaka Zulu (TV series)|Shaka Zulu]]'' miniseries<ref>{{cite web |url=http://remembered.co.za/shaka-kasenzangakhona-31 |work=Remembered |date=30 May 2013 |title=Remembering Shaka Zulu |accessdate=2015-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208233031/http://remembered.co.za/shaka-kasenzangakhona-31 |archivedate=8 December 2015 |df= }}</ref> in spite of the economic sanctions at the time.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1986-11-21/entertainment/ca-14929_1_shaka-zulu 'Shaka Zulu': Negative Metaphor For South African Blacks], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', November 21, 1986</ref> The planned 10-episode [[miniseries]] was based on the story of the king of the [[Zulu Kingdom|Zulu]], [[Shaka]] (reigned 1816 to 1828), and the writings of the British [[Merchant|traders]] with whom he interacted. In the same year, Agrama founded Harmony Gold.
Throughout 1984 and 1985, the original budget of about $1.75 million escalated quickly to $12 million, and the SABC justified the outlay to anticipated returns to be earned on the international market. Frank Agrama, however, noted the production was a "calculated gamble." ''Shaka Zulu'' had in fact, become the most expensive miniseries ever produced for television syndicate in the United States without pre-commitment to network or operation time to date. To ensure its marketability, Harmony Gold demanded that the well known white 'stars' appeared in the first episode to satisfy US advertisers, contrary to original script.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/archive/history-south-africa-alternative-visions-and-practices-joshua-brown|title=History from South Africa: Alternative Visions and Practices, page 301|publisher=Joshua Brown|date=1991}}</ref> The SABC's involvement was also completely removed for its international release due to legal implications set by [[apartheid]]. The opening credits featured Harmony Gold, with Frank Agrama listed as associate producer.
''Shaka Zulu'' went on to become a massive success worldwide, and has developed a [[cult following]] since its premiere in 1986. It has been the most repeatedly screened miniseries ever shown on syndicated television in the [[United States]]. By 1992, it had been seen by over 350 million viewers. The series dislodged John Marshall's ''[[The Hunters (1958 film)|The Hunters]]'' and the later ''[[The Gods Must be Crazy]]'' film series as the prime shaper of American perceptions of 'tribal' history in Southern Africa.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tlweb.latrobe.edu.au/humanities/screeningthepast/firstrelease/fr0703/ktfr15.html|title=Shaka Zulu and visual constructions of history|publisher=Screening the Past|date=30 June 2003}}</ref> Despite its success, the SABC failed to recoup the cost of their production due to unfair terms negotiated by Harmony Gold during production.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://camerainthesun.com/?p=25727|title=Joshua Sinclair on Shaka Zulu and apartheid|publisher=Camera in the Sun|date=September 2013}}</ref>
====''Robotech'' (1985)==== In the mid 1980s, Harmony Gold hired [[Carl Macek]] to adapt [[Japan]]ese animated programming for American broadcast release. Macek originally wanted to adapt ''[[The Super Dimension Fortress Macross]]'', but was instead forced to combine three different [[anime]] series together, which became ''[[Robotech]]'':
#''[[The Super Dimension Fortress Macross]]'' #''[[Super Dimension Cavalry Southern Cross]]'' #''[[Genesis Climber MOSPEADA]]''<ref>(NOTE: ''[[Super Dimension Century Orguss]]'' was originally planned to be used as the third "season" after ''Macross'' & ''Southern Cross''. However, that plan was scrapped due to right issues, which resulted in its replacement by ''MOSPEADA''.)</ref>
Harmony Gold's cited reasoning for combining these unrelated series was its decision to market ''Macross'' for American weekday syndication television, which required a minimum of 65 episodes at the time (thirteen weeks at five episodes per week). ''Macross'' and the two other series each had fewer episodes than required, since they originally aired in Japan as weekly series. The production was successful enough to merit a movie and a spin-off, ''[[Robotech II: The Sentinels]]''. Due to unforeseen economic circumstances, production was cancelled.
===Late 1980s to early 2000s=== In 1988, after the cancellation of ''[[Robotech II: The Sentinels]]'', a number of the staff were recruited to work at [[Saban Entertainment]]. Carl Macek, along with his friend [[Jerry Beck]] went on to found [[Streamline Pictures]]. Meanwhile, Harmony Gold began moving away from production and began focusing more on film distribution, dot-com ventures and real estate.
In 1998, Harmony Gold came under some scrutiny by several media executives for their role as a 'middleman' selling Paramount Pictures distribution rights to [[Mediaset]].
From 1999 to the early 2000s, the company began reverting to film production once again. They partnered with [[Netter Digital]] and hired [[Carl Macek]] to write ''[[Robotech 3000]]'', a spinoff of the original series. A promotional trailer was screened at the 2000 [[FanimeCon]] anime convention, and was widely panned by fans. [[Tatsunoko Production]]s attempted to salvage the project, to no avail.
===2000s and beyond=== Harmony Gold began heavily pushing ''Robotech'', first by releasing the series via a partnership with [[A.D. Vision|ADV Films]] in the US, and [[Manga Entertainment]] in the UK. In 2006, they partnered with [[Funimation|FUNimation Entertainment]] to release ''[[Robotech: The Shadow Chronicles]]'' on home video.
In August 2014, Harmony Gold released their first direct-to-video live-action feature in over a decade, ''[[The Big Goofy Secret of Hidden Pines]]''. Directed by Henri Charr, the film revolves around the comedic antics of two vacationers after they stumble upon Bigfoot.
==Legal problems==
Harmony Gold and its founder, Frank Agrama, have had an extensive history of legal troubles beginning in the early 2000s. Italian investigators discovered and froze bank accounts in Switzerland; five belonging to Agrama. According to another Italian daily, the ''[[Corriere della Sera]]'', the five accounts are said to contain SFr140 million ($109.5 million). This early investigation led to two high-profile trials.
===Mediaset conviction=== On November 29, 2006, federal agents raided Agrama's home and offices in connection with Italy's ongoing tax fraud, embezzlement and false accounting investigation of its former Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]]. Court documents revealed the recent search by FBI agents centered on Italian allegations that Agrama, Berlusconi and others fraudulently inflated the price of television rights originally purchased by Agrama so that millions of dollars in kickbacks could be paid to executives of Berlusconi's [[Mediaset]] media empire.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/nov/29/local/me-agrama29|title=Federal agents search producer's home, office|language=English|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=29 November 2006}}</ref>
On October 26, 2012, Agrama was convicted after a lengthy [[Trials involving Silvio Berlusconi#Mediaset television and cinema rights .28false accounting.2C embezzlement and tax fraud.29|trial]] involving the buying and selling of US film rights to the Mediaset media company at inflated prices.<ref name="bbcfraud">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20102215|title=Silvio Berlusconi sentenced for tax fraud | work=BBC News | date=26 October 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140207101452/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20102215|archivedate=7 February 2014}}</ref> As his age exceeded 70 years, he was exempted from direct imprisonment and served no actual jail time. According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', on November 21, 2006 prosecutors in [[Milan]], [[Italy]] charged Agrama, along with Berlusconi and ten others, in a trial over tax fraud, embezzlement and false accounting at Mediaset.
===Mediatrade acquittal===
In October 2011, Paddy Chan Mei-yiu and Katherine Hsu May-chun, along with nine others (including Frank Agrama and [[Pier Silvio Berlusconi]], son of Silvio Berlusconi), were indicted by a Milan court and charged with buying rights for US television series and movies, then reselling them to broadcasting rights firm Mediatrade (a subsidiary of Mediaset) at inflated prices and laundering the money in a complex scheme. The four companies allegedly involved in this scheme were Wiltshire Trading, Harmony Gold, CS Secretaries and Loong Po Management.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mediaset-mediatrade-idUSKBN0E21FH20140522#DvRYAqYgWZjC0iay.97|title=Hong Kong set to hand over Berlusconi-related evidence|publisher=South China Morning Post|date=7 June 2013}}</ref>
According to prosecutors, Chan met Agrama in [[Cannes]], [[France]] in the late 1970s at a trade fair and they decided to form a partnership to trade movie rights internationally. Chan organized a Hong Kong-based Harmony Gold Limited in 1979, records from the city's Companies Registry show. In the same year, Agrama organized Agrama Film Enterprises on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles. Four years later, he set up Harmony Gold. He later also became the Los Angeles representative of another Hong Kong company established by Chan, Wiltshire Trading.
Prosecutors estimated the illicit profits between 1988 and 1999 amounted to US$170 million. Earlier in 2005, Swiss investigators froze 150 million francs (HK$1.29 billion) at a UBS branch in Lugano belonging to Harmony Gold, Wiltshire Trading and other companies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1324781/italian-prosecutors-say-hong-kong-women-were-key-massive-money|title=Italian prosecutors say Hong Kong women were key to a massive money-laundering scheme|publisher=South China Morning Post|date=22 May 2014}}</ref>
On July 24, 2014, [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] reported that some of the charges have been dropped due to expiring [[statute of limitations]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117957401.html?categoryid=22&cs=1 | title=Judge throws out some Berlusconi charges | author=Nick Vivarelli | work=Variety | accessdate=2015-12-11 | date=2014}}</ref> An appeals hearing was set to take place January 20, 2016.<ref name="afr">{{cite web|url=http://www.e-duesse.it/News/Televisione/Mediatrade-il-20-gennaio-inizia-l-appello-195937|work=e-duesse|date=November 9, 2015|title=Mediatrade, il 20 gennaio inizia l’appello|accessdate=December 11, 2015}}</ref> On January 18, 2016, all charges against Frank Agrama and five other people were dropped. Berlusconi and Mediaset Chairman Fedele Confalonieri were convicted and were sentenced to 13 months of imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mediaset-ceo-tax-evasion-sentence-876702|author=Ariston Anderson|work=Hollywood Reporter| date=2016|title=Mediaset CEO Pier-Silvio Berlusconi Gets 14-Month Sentence in Tax Evasion Case}}]]</ref>
==Legal issues regarding ''Macross'' copyright== Harmony Gold, via its license of ''[[Robotech]]'', is the co-copyright owner in the US for images of mecha from the component series of the show, ''[[Super Dimension Fortress Macross]]'', ''[[Super Dimension Cavalry Southern Cross]]'', and ''[[Genesis Climber MOSPEADA]]''. They have pursued multiple lawsuits against anyone using mecha which even vaguely resemble these designs.
Most notably, many early designs used in ''[[Battletech]]'', such as the ''Warhammer'', ''Valkyrie'', and ''Marauder'', were licensed directly from the Japanese producers of Macross, with the overlapping rights mistake not being realized for nearly a decade. Harmony Gold sued [[FASA]], and as a result these designs were removed from the game. Fan outcry over 'The Unseen' has led to multiple attempts to negotiate deals allowing for resumed use of the designs, but despite in one case a sourcebook going to press before being abruptly pulled, no deal has ever been reached. As a result of the failed negotiations, the producers of Battletech ruled that any designs not developed in house would no longer be used in order to avoid future issues.
Harmony Gold issued cease and desist orders against sites displaying images and trailers from the deceased video game MechWarrior, due to one of the mechs used in the trailer being a ''Warhammer''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/5352295/mechwarrior-5-runs-into-legal-trouble | title=Mechwarrior 5 Runs Into Legal Trouble | author=Luke Plunkett | work=Kotaku | year=2009 | accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref> The company claims that the images portray ’mechs that they own the rights to, according to a legal settlement from 1996.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://alex.kaempen.org/harmony_gold_v._fasa.html | title=Harmony Gold USA vs FASA | author=UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ILLINOIS, EASTERN DIVISION | work=Legal Filing | year=1996 | accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref>
In 2013, Harmony Gold claimed in Federal Court that [[Hasbro]]'s [[San Diego Comic-Con International|SDCC 2013]] exclusive set "G.I. Joe vs Transformers The Epic Conclusion" violated their copyright license and trademarks on the animated Japanese [[Macross]] TV series (1982–84).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://courthousenews.com/2013/07/23/Transformers.pdf|title=HARMONY GOLD USA, INC vs HASBRO|work=www.courthousenews.com|accessdate=April 29, 2015|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014085251/http://courthousenews.com/2013/07/23/Transformers.pdf|archivedate=October 14, 2013|df=}}</ref> On September 23, 2013, Harmony Gold's suit against Hasbro was dismissed with prejudice, and Hasbro was allowed to continue to sell the sets.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-10-17/harmony-gold-usa-v-hasbro-case-dismissed | title = Harmony Gold USA v. Hasbro Case Dismissed|work=www.animenewsnetwork.com|accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref>
The legal status of Harmony Gold's license to Macross was dubious. Harmony Gold's license for ''Macross'' came from [[Tatsunoko Production]], but Japanese courts ruled that it was [[Studio Nue]] (creators of the series) that controls the ''Macross'' intellectual property. The license Tatsunoko was given was for international distribution outside Japan only, and does not allow them to control the intellectual property. According to the US Copyright Office, Harmony Gold is the Co-Copyright owner until 2021.
In November 2016, Harmony Gold initiated arbitration against Tatsunoko, to which Tatsunoko responded with counterclaims.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Knaub|first1=Kelly|title=Judge OKs Production Co.'s $850K Award In License Dispute - Law360|url=https://www.law360.com/articles/957616/judge-oks-production-co-s-850k-award-in-license-dispute|website=Law360|accessdate=19 September 2017|location=New York|date=August 25, 2017}}</ref> With the exception of the original visual depictions of 41 characters, which are owned by [[Big West Advertising]] not Tatsunoko, the arbitrator found that Harmony Gold had the rights to ''The Super Dimension Fortress Macross'', ''The Super Dimension Cavalry Southern Cross'', and ''Genesis Climber Mospeada'' until their expiry on March 14, 2021, as per the licensing agreement. Harmony Gold also holds several trademarks related to Macross and its trademark for the Macross series was renewed on December 26, 2012. The expiration date for these will be ten years from that date, on December 26, 2022 but the pending expiration of the licensing agreement could affect the trademark ownership before 2022.<ref>{{cite web|title=Harmony Gold's Macross, Mospeada, Southern Cross Licenses Still Expire in 2021|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-09-14/harmony-gold-macross-mospeada-southern-cross-licenses-still-expire-in-2021/.121372|website=Anime News Network|accessdate=19 September 2017|date=14 September 2017}}</ref>

==Alternative names: MasterVision== Harmony Gold was known in the [[United Kingdom]] as MasterVision in the VHS pre-certs sector. They released the same films on another UK label Kids Cartoon Collection for the home market during the 1985. Finding a MasterVision or Kids Cartoon Collection (a.k.a. Harmony Gold in the UK) is like striking a pot of Harmony Gold, as they were a rare brand of VHS in the UK. Some English dubs by Harmony Gold only made it to the UK under these UK labels of them, ''The Little Train'' was one of their notable UK exclusive English speaking dubs for instance, as there are no signs of any US versions, possibly due to its rare existence in the US. However, this mentioned dub did get a semi US Harmony Gold dub in Mexican in the NTSC region, so it did hit one NTSC dub in the Americas. This notable rare film dub by them was made from footage from a 1980 Italian URBS production instead of their normal fare in Japan using footage by Toei and Tatsunoko. This noted film was released in 1985 by them on both Kids Cartoon Collection and MaserVision, making it one of their first and only UK exclusives, as far as English dubs by them are concerned. These VHS companies by them also released the standard fare from their USA branch, for example ''The Brave Frog'' and ''Robotech'' in the UK.

revision.text:
{{Infobox language | name=Hejazi Arabic | nativename= {{big|{{lang|ar|حجازي}}}} ''Ḥijāzi'' | pronunciation={{nowrap|{{IPA|/ħi'd͡ʒaːzi/}}}} | states=[[Hejaz]] region, [[Saudi Arabia]] | speakers=14.5 million | date=2011 | ref=<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/acw|title=Arabic, Hijazi Spoken|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en}}</ref> | familycolor=Afro-Asiatic | fam2=[[Semitic languages|Semitic]] | fam3=[[Central Semitic languages|Central Semitic]] | fam4=[[Arabic languages|Arabic]] | fam5=[[Peninsular Arabic|Peninsular]] | ancestor = [[Old Hijazi|Old Hejazi]] | script=[[Arabic alphabet]] | iso3=acw | glotto=hija1235 | glottorefname=Hejazi Arabic | notice=IPA | map= Distribution of Hejazi Arabic in Saudi Arabia.png | mapcaption= {{Legend|#2E8B57|regions where Hejazi is the language of the majority}} {{Legend|#9ACD32|regions considered as part of modern Hejaz region}} }} '''Hejazi Arabic''' or '''Hijazi Arabic''' ({{lang-ar|حجازي}} ''{{transl|ar|ḥijāzī}}''), also known as '''West Arabian Arabic''', is a [[Varieties of Arabic|variety of Arabic]] spoken in the [[Hejaz]] region in [[Saudi Arabia]]. Strictly speaking, there are two main groups of dialects spoken in the [[Hejaz]] region,<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Alzaidi|2014|p=73}}</ref> one by the urban population, originally spoken in the major cities of [[Jeddah]], [[Mecca]] and [[Medina]], and another by the [[Bedouin]] or rural populations. However, the term most often applies to the urban variety which is discussed in this article.
In antiquity, the Hejaz was home to the [[Old Higazi|Old Hejazi]] dialect of Arabic. Old Hejazi is distinct from modern Hejazi Arabic, and represents an older linguistic layer wiped out by centuries of migration, but which happens to share the imperative prefix vowel /a-/ with the modern dialect.
== Classification == Hejazi Arabic belongs to the western [[Peninsular Arabic]] branch of the [[Arabic language]], which itself is a [[Semitic language]]. It includes features of both urban and bedouin dialects giving its history between the ancient urban cities of [[Medina]] and [[Mecca]] and the bedouin tribes that lived on the outskirts of these cities.
=== Features === Also referred to as the sedentary Hejazi dialect, this is the form most commonly associated with the term "Hejazi Arabic", and is spoken in the urban centers of the region, such as Jeddah, Mecca, and Medina. With respect to the axis of [[bedouin]] versus sedentary dialects of the Arabic language, this dialect group exhibits features of both. Like other sedentary dialects, the urban Hejazi dialect is less conservative than the bedouin varieties in some aspects and has therefore shed some Classical forms and features that are still present in bedouin dialects, these include gender-number disagreement, and the feminine marker ''-n'' (see [[Varieties of Arabic]]). But in contrast to bedouin dialects, the constant use of full vowels and the absence of [[vowel reduction]] plus the distinction between the emphatic letters {{angbr|[[ض]]}} and {{angbr|[[ظ]]}} is generally retained.
==== Innovative features ====
# The present progressive tense is marked by the prefix {{lang|acw|بـ}} {{IPA|/bi/}} or {{lang|acw|قاعد}} {{IPA|/gaːʕid/}} as in {{lang|acw|بيدرس}} {{IPA|/bijidrus/}} or {{lang|acw|قاعد يدرس}} {{IPA|/gaːʕid jidrus/}} ("he is studying"). # The future tense is marked by the prefix {{lang|acw|حـ}} {{IPA|/ħa/}} as in {{lang|acw|حيدرس}} {{IPA|/ħajidrus/}} ("he is going to study"). # the internal passive form, which in Hejazi, is replaced by the pattern ({{lang|acw|أنفعل}} {{IPA|/anfaʕal/}}, {{lang|acw|ينفعل}} {{IPA|/jinfaʕil/}}). # The final ''-n'' in present tense plural verb forms is no longer employed (e.g. {{lang|acw|يركبوا}} {{IPA|/jirkabu/}} instead of {{lang|acw|يركبون}} {{IPA|/jarkəbuːn/}}). # The dominant case ending before the 3rd person masculine singular pronoun is ''-u'', rather than the ''-a'' that is prevalent in bedouin dialects. For example, {{lang|acw|بيته}} {{IPA|/beːtu/}} ("his house"), {{lang|acw|عنده}} {{IPA|/ʕindu/}} ("he has"), {{lang|acw|أعرفه}} {{IPA|/aʕrifu/}} ("I know him"). [[File:Semitic-map-english.gif|thumb|323x323px|right|Approximate distribution of Arabic language around the 1st century in [[Hejaz]] and [[Najd]]]]
==== Conservative features ==== # Hejazi Arabic does not employ [[double negative|double negation]], nor does it append the negation particles ''-sh'' to negate verbs: Hejazi {{lang|acw|ما اعرف}} {{IPA|/maː aʕrif/}} ("I don't know"), as opposed to [[Egyptian Arabic|Egyptian]] {{lang|ar|معرفش}} {{IPA|/maʕrafʃ/}} and [[Palestinian Arabic|Palestinian]] {{lang|ar|بعرفش}} {{IPA|/baʕrafiʃ/}}. #The present indicative tense is not marked by any prefixes as in {{lang|acw|يِدْرُس}} {{IPA|/jidrus/}} ("he studies"), as opposed to [[Egyptian Arabic|Egyptian]] {{lang|ar|بيدرس}}. # The prohibitive mood of Classical Arabic is preserved in the imperative: {{lang|acw|لا تروح}} {{IPA|/laː tiruːħ/}} ("don't go"). # The possessive suffixes are generally preserved in their Classical forms. For example, {{lang|acw|بيتكم}} {{IPA|/beːtakum/}} "your (pl) house". # The plural first person pronoun is {{lang|ar|نحنا}} {{IPA|/niħna/}} or {{lang|ar|إحنا}} {{IPA|/iħna/}}, as opposed to the bedouin {{lang|ar|حنّا}} {{IPA|/ħənna/}} or {{lang|ar|إنّا}} {{IPA|/ənna/}}. # When used to indicate location, the preposition {{lang|acw|في}} {{IPA|/fi/}} is preferred to {{lang|acw|بـ}} {{IPA|/b/}}. In bedouin dialects, the preference differs by region. # Less restriction on the distribution of {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/u/}}. # The glottal stop can be added to final syllables ending in a vowel as a way of emphasising. # Compared to neighboring dialects, urban Hejazi retains most of the short vowels of [[Classical Arabic]] with no [[vowel reduction]], for example: :: {{lang|ar|سمكة}} {{IPA|/samaka/}} ("fish"), as opposed to bedouin {{IPA|[sməka]}}. :: {{lang|ar|نُطْق}} {{IPA|/nutˤg/}} ("pronunciation"), as opposed to bedouin {{IPA|[nətˤg]}}. :: {{lang|ar|ضربَته}} {{IPA|/dˤarabatu/}} ("she hit him"), as opposed to bedouin {{IPA|[ðˤrabətah]}}. :: {{lang|ar|وَلَدُه}} {{IPA|/waladu/}} ("his son"), as opposed to bedouin {{IPA|[wlədah]}}. :: {{lang|ar|عندَكُم}} {{IPA|/ʕindakum/}} ("in your possession" pl.), as opposed to bedouin {{IPA|[ʕəndəkum]}}, Egyptian {{IPA|[ʕanduku]}}, and Levantine {{IPA|[ʕandkon]}}.
== History == The Arabic of today is derived principally from the old dialects of Central and North Arabia which were divided by the classical Arab grammarians into three groups: [[Hejaz]], [[Najd]], and the language of the tribes in adjoining areas. Though the modern Hejazi dialects has developed markedly since the development of Classical Arabic, and Modern Standard Arabic is quite distinct from the modern dialect of Hejaz. Standard Arabic now differs considerably from modern Hejazi Arabic in terms of its phonology, morphology, syntax, and lexicon,<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Phonology and Morphology of Arabic|last=Watson|first=Janet|publisher=Oxford university press|year=2002|isbn=|location=|pages=8, 9}}</ref> such diglossia in Arabic began to emerge at the latest in the sixth century CE when oral poets recited their poetry in a proto-Classical Arabic based on archaic dialects which differed greatly from their own.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Semitic Languages: Outline of a Comparative Grammar|last=Lipinski|first=|publisher=|year=1997|isbn=|location=|pages=75}}</ref>
Historically, it is not well known in which stage of Arabic the shift from the [[Semitic languages#Phonology|Proto-Semitic]] pair {{IPA|/q, g/}} to Hejazi {{IPA|/g, d͡ʒ/}} {{angbr|[[ج]] ,[[ق]]}} occurred, although it has been attested as early as the eighth century CE, and it can be explained by a [[chain shift]] {{IPA|/q/}}* → {{IPA|/g/}} → {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}}<ref>{{Cite book|title=Cours de phonétique arabe|last=Cantineau|first=Jean|publisher=Libraire C. Klincksieck|year=1960|isbn=|location=Paris, France|pages=67|language=French}}</ref> that occurred in one of two ways:
# Drag Chain: Proto-Semitic [[Gimel|gīm]] {{IPA|/g/}} [[Palatalization (sound change)|palatalized]] to Hejazi {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}} jīm first, opening up a space at the position of {{IPA|[g]}}, which qāf {{IPA|/q/}} (or {{IPA|/kˤ/}}) then moved to fill the empty space resulting in Hejazi {{IPA|/g/}} gāf, restoring structural symmetrical relationships present in the pre-Arabic system.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Freeman|first=Aaron|date=2015|title=The Linguistic Geography of Dorsal Consonants in Syria|url=http://www.ling.upenn.edu/~aaronfr/L568-final-Freeman.pdf|journal=The Linguistic Geography of Dorsal Consonants in Syria|publication-place=University of Pennsylvania|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Öhrnberg|first=Kaj|date=2013|title=Travelling Through Time|url=|journal=Studia Orientalia 114|volume=|pages=524|via=}}</ref> # Push Chain: Proto-Semitic [[Qoph|qāf]] presumably {{IPA|/q/}} (or {{IPA|/kʼ/}}) changed to Hejazi {{IPA|/g/}} gāf first, which resulted in pushing the original gīm {{IPA|/g/}} forward in articulation to become Hejazi {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}} jīm, but since most modern qāf dialects as well as standard Arabic also have jīm, hence the push-chain of qāf to gāf first can be discredited,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heinrichs|first=Wolfhart|date=|title=Ibn Khaldūn as a Historical Linguist with an Excursus on the Question of Ancient gāf|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B8F_PW9P6dqlcWc1OUpBcFpLZTA/view|journal=Harvard University|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> although there are good grounds for believing that old Arabic qāf had both voiced {{IPAblink|g}} and voiceless {{IPAblink|q}} allophones; and after that gīm {{IPA|/g/}} was fronted to {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}} jīm, possibly as a result of pressure from the allophones.<ref>Blanc 1969: 11, Travelling Through Time, Essays in honour of Kaj Öhrnberg</ref>
<small>* The original value of [[Semitic languages#Phonology|Proto-Semitic qāf]] was probably an [[Emphatic consonant|emphatic]] {{IPAblink|kʼ}} not {{IPAblink|q}}.</small> == Phonology == {{Main article|Hejazi Arabic phonology}}In general, Hejazi native phonemic inventory consists of 26 to 28 [[consonant]] [[Phoneme|phonemes]] depending on the speaker's background and formality, while it has an eight-vowel system, consisting of three short and five long [[Vowel|vowels]] {{IPA|/a, u, i, aː, uː, oː, iː, eː/}}, in addition to two diphthongs {{IPA|/aw, aj/}}.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdoh|2010|p=84}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Omar|1975|p=xv}}</ref> [[Consonant length]] and [[Vowel length]] are both distinctive in Hejazi.
The main phonological feature that differentiates urban Hejazi from the neighboring urban and rural dialects of the [[Arabian peninsula]], is the constant use of full vowels and the absence of [[vowel reduction]], for example {{lang|ar|قلت لك}} 'I told you' (to a female), is pronounced {{IPA|[gʊltalːɪk]}} or {{IPA|[gʊltalɪk]}} in Hejazi with full vowels but pronounced with the reduced vowel {{IPA|[ə]}} as {{IPA|[gəltələk]}} or {{IPA|[gəltələt͡s]}} in [[Najdi Arabic|Najdi]]. In general it also retains the distinction between the letters {{angbr|[[Ḍād|ض]]}} and {{angbr|[[Ẓāʾ|ظ]]}}, but alternates between the pronunciations of the letters {{angbr|[[Ṯāʾ|ث]]}} ,{{angbr|[[Ḏāl|ذ]]}}, and {{angbr|[[Ẓāʾ|ظ]]}}. (See {{slink||Writing system}}, below.)
A conservative phonological feature that Hejazi holds is the lack of [[Palatalization (sound change)#Semitic languages|palatalization]] for the letters {{lang|acw|ك}} {{IPA|/k/}}, {{lang|acw|ق}} {{IPA|/g/}} and {{lang|acw|ج}} {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}}, unlike in other [[Peninsular Arabic|peninsular dialects]] where they can be [[Palatalization (sound change)#Varieties of Arabic|palatalized]] and merged with other phonemes in certain positions<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Oxford Handbook of Arabic Linguistics|last=Owens|first=Owens|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=259}}</ref> (to [<nowiki/>[[Voiceless palato-alveolar affricate|t͡ʃ]]], [<nowiki/>[[Voiceless alveolar affricate|t͡s]]], [<nowiki/>[[Voiceless postalveolar fricative|ʃ]]], or [<nowiki/>[[Voiceless alveolar fricative#Voiceless%20alveolar%20sibilant|s]]] in case of ك, [<nowiki/>[[Voiced palato-alveolar affricate|d͡ʒ]]] or [<nowiki/>[[Voiced alveolar affricate|d͡z]]] in case of ق and {{IPAblink|j}} in case of ج), it is also worth mentioning that this trait of non-palatalization is becoming common across Saudi Arabia especially in urban centers, another feature is that the ل {{IPA|/l/}} is only [[Velarization|velarized]] to /[[Alveolar lateral approximant#Velarized alveolar lateral approximant|ɫ]]/ in the word الله /aɫːaːh/ 'god' (except when it follows an /i/: بسمِ الله {{IPA|/bism'''i'''lːaːh/}} or لله {{IPA|/l'''i'''lːaːh/}}) and words derived from it, unlike other peninsular dialects where it might be velarized [[Allophone|allophonically]], as in {{lang|acw|عقل}} pronounced {{IPA|[ʕaɡe̞l]}} in Hejazi but {{IPA|[ʕaɡəɫ]}} in other peninsular Arabic dialects.

colspan="2" |[[Denti-alveolar consonant|Denti-alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Pharyngeal consonant|Pharyngeal]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- style="font-size: 80%;" ! plain  ![[Emphatic consonant|emphatic]] |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align: left;" |[[Nasal stop|Nasal]] |{{IPA link|m}} | |{{IPA link|n}} | | | | | |- ! rowspan="2" style="text-align: left;" |[[Occlusive]] ! style="text-align: left; font-size: 80%;" |[[Voiceless consonant|voiceless]] |({{IPA link|p}}) | |{{IPA link|t̪|t}} |{{IPA link|tˤ}} | |{{IPA link|k}} | |{{IPA link|ʔ}} |- ! style="text-align: left; font-size: 80%;" |[[Voiced consonant|voiced]] |{{IPA link|b}} | |{{IPA link|d̪|d}} |{{IPA link|dˤ}} |{{IPA link|d͡ʒ}} |{{IPA link|ɡ}} | | |- ! rowspan="2" style="text-align: left;" |[[Fricative]] ! style="text-align: left; font-size: 80%;" |[[Voiceless consonant|voiceless]] |{{IPA link|f}} |{{IPA link|θ}}* |{{IPA link|s̪|s}} |{{IPA link|sˤ}} |{{IPA link|ʃ}} |{{IPA link|x}} |{{IPA link|ħ}} |{{IPA link|h}} |- ! style="text-align: left; font-size: 80%;" |[[Voiced consonant|voiced]] |({{IPA link|v}}) |{{IPA link|ð}}* |{{IPA link|z̪|z}} |{{IPA link|zˤ}} | |{{IPA link|ɣ}} |{{IPA link|ʕ}} | |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align: left;" |[[Trill consonant|Trill]] | | |{{IPA link|r}} | | | | | |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align: left;" |[[Approximant]] | | |{{IPA link|l}} |({{IPA link|ɫ}}) |{{IPA link|j}} |{{IPA link|w}} | | |} Phonetic notes: * due to the influence of [[Modern Standard Arabic]], {{IPAblink|q}} has been introduced as an [[allophone]] of {{IPA|/ɡ/}} {{angbr|[[ق]]}} in few words and phrases as in {{lang|acw|القاهرة}} ('Cairo') which is [[Narrow versus broad transcription|phonemically]] {{IPA|/alˈ'''g'''aːhira/}} but can be pronounced as {{IPA|[alˈ'''q'''aːhɪra]}} or less likely {{IPA|[alˈ'''g'''aːhɪra]}} depending on the speaker, although older speakers prefer {{IPAblink|g}} in all positions. * the marginal phoneme /[[Alveolar lateral approximant#Velarized alveolar lateral approximant|ɫ]]/ only occurs in the word الله /aɫːaːh/ ('god') and words derived from it, it contrasts with /l/ in والله /waɫːa/ ('i swear') vs. ولَّا /walːa/ ('or'). *the [[affricate]] {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}} {{angbr|[[ج]]}} and the trill {{IPA|/r/}} {{angbr|[[ر]]}} are realised as a {{IPAblink|ʒ}} and a tap {{IPAblink|ɾ}} respectively by a number of speakers or in a number of words. *the reintroduced phoneme {{IPA|/θ/}} {{angbr|[[Ṯāʾ|ث]]}} is partially used as an alternative phoneme, while most speakers merge it with {{IPA|/t/}} or {{IPA|/s/}} depending on the word. *the reintroduced phoneme {{IPA|/ð/}} {{angbr|[[Ḏāl|ذ]]}} is partially used as an alternative phoneme, while most speakers merge it with {{IPA|/d/}} or {{IPA|/z/}} depending on the word. * the classicized {{IPAblink|ðˤ}} is an optional allophone for ⟨[[Ẓāʾ|ظ]]⟩, but it is always used when pronouncing the letter's name which is [ˈðˤaːʔ]. In general, urban Hejazi speakers pronounce it as /zˤ/ or merge it with /dˤ/ depending on the word. *{{IPA|/p/}} ⟨[[Pe (Persian letter)|پ]]⟩ and {{IPA|/v/}} ⟨[[Ve (Arabic letter)|ڤ]]⟩ which exist only in foreign words, are used by a number of speakers and can be substituted by {{IPA|/b/}} ⟨[[ب]]⟩ and {{IPA|/f/}} ⟨[[ف]]⟩ respectively depending on the speaker. *{{IPA|/tʃ/}} occurs only in foreign words and it is not considered to be part of the phonemic inventory but as a [[Consonant cluster|sequence]] of {{IPA|/t/}} ⟨[[ت]]⟩ and {{IPA|/ʃ/}} ⟨[[ش]]⟩, as in تشيلي {{IPA|/ˈtʃiːli/}} or {{IPA|/tʃiːleː/}} ('Chile').
=== Vowels === {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align: center;" |+Vowel phonemes of Hejazi ! rowspan="2" | ! colspan="2" |Short ! colspan="2" |Long |- ![[Front vowel|Front]] ![[Back vowel|Back]] ![[Front vowel|Front]] ![[Back vowel|Back]] |- style="text-align: center;" ![[Close vowel|Close]] | rowspan="2" |{{IPA|i}} | rowspan="2" |{{IPA|u}} |{{IPA link|iː}} |{{IPA link|uː}} |- style="text-align: center;" ![[Mid vowel|Mid]] |{{IPA link|e̞ː|eː}} |{{IPA link|o̞ː|oː}} |- style="text-align: center;" ![[Open vowel|Open]] | colspan="2" |{{IPA|a}} | colspan="2" |{{IPA link|aː}} |} Phonetic notes: *{{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/aː/}} are always pronounced either as a front {{IPAblink|a}} or a central {{IPAblink|ä}} depending on the speaker, except in some words such as {{lang|acw|ألمانيا}} {{IPA|[almɑːnja]}} ('Germany'), {{lang|acw|يابان}} {{IPA|[jaːbɑːn]}} ('Japan') and {{lang|acw|بابا}} {{IPA|[bɑːbɑ]}} ('dad') where they are pronounced with the back vowel {{IPAblink|ɑ}}. *{{IPA|/oː/}} and {{IPA|/eː/}} are pronounced as true [[mid vowel]]s {{IPAblink|o̞ː}} and {{IPAblink|e̞ː}} respectively. * short {{IPA|/u/}} is pronounced allophonically as {{IPAblink|ʊ}} or {{IPAblink|o̞}} in word initial or medial syllables and strictly as {{IPAblink|u}} at the end of words or before {{IPAblink|w}} or when isolate. * short {{IPA|/i/}} is pronounced allophonically as {{IPAblink|ɪ}} or {{IPAblink|e̞}} in word initial or medial syllables and strictly as {{IPAblink|i}} at the end of words or before {{IPAblink|j}} or when isolate.
==== Monophthongization ==== Most of the occurrences of the two diphthongs {{IPA|/aj/}} and {{IPA|/aw/}} in the [[Classical Arabic]] period underwent [[monophthongization]] in Hejazi, and are realized as the long vowels {{IPA|/eː/}} and {{IPA|/oː/}} respectively, but they are still preserved as diphthongs in a number of words which created a contrast with the long vowels {{IPA|/uː/}}, {{IPA|/oː/}}, {{IPA|/iː/}} and {{IPA|/eː/}}. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !Example (without [[Arabic diacritics|diacritics]]) !Meaning !Hejazi Arabic !Modern Standard Arabic |- | rowspan="3" | {{lang|ar|دوري}} |league |{{IPA|/d'''aw'''ri/}} | rowspan="2" |{{IPA|/d'''aw'''ri/}} |- |my turn |{{IPA|/d'''oː'''ri/}} |- |turn around! |{{IPA|/d'''uː'''ri/}} |{{IPA|/d'''uː'''ri/}} |} Not all instances of mid vowels are a result of monophthongization, some are from grammatical processes {{lang|ar|قالوا}} {{IPA|/gaːl'''u'''/}} 'they said' → {{lang|ar|قالوا لها}} {{IPA|/gaːl'''oː'''laha/}} 'they said to her' (opposed to Classical Arabic {{lang|ar|قالوا لها}} {{IPA|/qaːl'''uː''' lahaː/}}), and some occur in modern [[Portmanteau|Portmanteau words]] e.g. {{lang|ar|ليش}} {{IPA|/leːʃ/}} 'why?' (from Classical Arabic {{lang|ar|لأي}} {{IPA|/liʔaj/}} 'for what' and {{lang|ar|شيء}} {{IPA|/ʃajʔ/}} 'thing').
== Vocabulary == Hejazi vocabulary derives primarily from Arabic Semitic roots. The urban Hejazi vocabulary differs in some respect from that of other dialects in the Arabian Peninsula. For example, there are fewer specialized terms related to desert life, and more terms related to seafaring and fishing. Loanwords are mainly of [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Romance languages|Latin]] ([[French language|French]] and [[Italian language|Italian]]) and [[English language|English]] origins, and due to the diverse origins of the inhabitants of Hejazi cities, some loanwords are only used by some families. A number of old loanwords are fading or became obsolete due to the influence of [[Modern Standard Arabic]] and their association with lower social class and education,<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Alahmadi|2015|p=45}}</ref> e.g. {{lang|ar|كنديشن}} {{IPA|/kunˈdeːʃan/}} "[[Air conditioning|air conditioner]]" (from English ''Condition'') was replaced by Standard Arabic {{lang|ar|مكيّف}} {{IPA|/mukajːif/}}. Most of the loanwords are nouns (with a change of meaning sometimes) as in: {{lang|ar|جزمة}} {{IPA|/d͡ʒazma/}} "[[shoe]]" from Turkish {{wikt-lang|tr|çizme}} {{IPA|/t͡ʃizme/}} originally meaning "[[boot]]" or {{lang|ar|كُبري}} {{IPA|/kubri/}} "[[overpass]]" from {{wikt-lang|tr|köprü}} {{IPA|/køpry/}} originally meaning "[[bridge]]".
Some general Hejazi expressions include {{lang|ar|بالتوفيق}} {{IPA|/bitːawfiːg/}} "good luck", {{lang|ar|إيوه}} {{IPA|/ʔiːwa/}} "yes", {{lang|ar|لأ}} {{IPA|/laʔ/}} "no", {{lang|ar|لسة}} {{IPA|/lisːa/}} "not yet", {{lang|ar|قد}} {{IPA|/ɡid/}} or {{lang|ar|قيد}} {{IPA|/ɡiːd/}} "already", {{lang|ar|دحين}} {{IPA|/daħiːn/}} or {{IPA|/daħeːn/}} "now", {{lang|ar|أبغى}} {{IPA|/ʔabɣa/}} "I want", {{lang|ar|لو سمحت}} {{IPA|/law samaħt/}} "please/excuse me" to a male and {{lang|ar|لو سمحتي}} {{IPA|/law samaħti/}} "please/excuse me" to a female.
=== Portmanteau === A common feature in Hejazi vocabulary is [[Portmanteau|portmanteau words]] (also called a ''[[Blend word|blend]]'' in linguistics); in which parts of multiple [[word]]s or their [[Phone (phonetics)|phones]] (sounds) are combined into a new word, it is especially innovative in making [[Interrogative words]], examples include: * {{lang|ar|إيوه}} ({{IPA|/ʔiːwa/}}, "yes") : from {{lang|ar|إي}} ({{IPA|/ʔiː/}}, "yes") and {{lang|ar|و}} ({{IPA|/wa/}}, "and") and {{lang|ar|الله}} ({{IPA|/aɫːaːh/}}, "god"). * {{lang|ar|معليش}} ({{IPA|/maʕleːʃ/}}, is it ok?/sorry) : from {{lang|ar|ما}} ({{IPA|/maː/}}, nothing) and {{lang|ar|عليه}} ({{IPA|/ʕalajh/}}, on him) and {{lang|ar|شيء}} ({{IPA|/ʃajʔ/}}, thing). * {{lang|ar|إيش}} ({{IPA|/ʔeːʃ/}}, "what?") : from {{lang|ar|أي}} ({{IPA|/aj/}}, "which") and {{lang|ar|شيء}} ({{IPA|/ʃajʔ/}}, "thing"). * {{lang|ar|ليش}} ({{IPA|/leːʃ/}}, "why?") : from {{lang|ar|لأي}} ({{IPA|/liʔaj/}}, for what) and {{lang|ar|شيء}} ({{IPA|/ʃajʔ/}}, "thing"). * {{lang|ar|فين}} ({{IPA|/feːn/}}, where?) : from {{lang|ar|في}} ({{IPA|/fiː/}}, in) and {{lang|ar|أين}} ({{IPA|/ʔajn/}}, where). * {{lang|ar|إلين}} ({{IPA|/ʔileːn/}}, "until") : from {{lang|ar|إلى}} ({{IPA|/ʔilaː/}}, "to") and {{lang|ar|أن}} ({{IPA|/an/}}, "that"). * {{lang|ar|دحين}} ({{IPA|/daħiːn/}} or {{IPA|/daħeːn/}}, "now") or {{lang|ar|ذحين}} ({{IPA|/ðaħiːn/}} or {{IPA|/ðaħeːn/}}, "now") : from {{lang|ar|ذا}} ({{IPA|/ðaː/}}, "this") and {{lang|ar|الحين}} ({{IPA|/alħiːn/}}, part of time). * {{lang|ar|بعدين}} ({{IPA|/baʕdeːn/}}, later) : from {{lang|ar|بعد}} (baʕd, after) and {{lang|ar|أَيْن}} (ʔayn, part of time). * {{lang|ar|علشان}} or {{lang|ar|عشان}} ({{IPA|/ʕalaʃaːn/}} or {{IPA|/ʕaʃaːn/}}, "because") : from {{lang|ar|على}} ({{IPA|/ʕalaː/}}, "on") and {{lang|ar|شأن}} ({{IPA|/ʃaʔn/}}, "matter"). * {{lang|ar|كمان}} ({{IPA|/kamaːn/}}, "also") : from {{lang|ar|كما}} ({{IPA|/kamaː/}}, "like") and {{lang|ar|أن}} ({{IPA|/ʔan/}}, "that"). * {{lang|ar|يلّا}} ({{IPA|/jaɫːa/}}, come on) : from {{lang|ar|يا}} ({{IPA|/jaː/}}, "o!") and {{lang|ar|الله}} ({{IPA|/aɫːaːh/}}, "god").
=== Numerals === The Cardinal number system in Hejazi is much more simplified than the Classical Arabic<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Kheshaifaty|1997}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" ! numbers 1-10 !! [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] !!11-20 !! [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] !! 10s !! [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] !! 100s !! [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] |- | 1 {{lang|acw|واحد}} || {{IPA|/waːħid/}} || 11 {{lang|acw|احدعش}} || {{IPA|/iħdaʕaʃ/}} || 10 {{lang|acw|عشرة}} || {{IPA|/ʕaʃara/}} || 100 {{lang|acw|مية}} {{lang|acw|ميَّة}} || {{IPA|/mijːa/}} || 1000 {{lang|acw|ألف}} || {{IPA|/alf/}} |}
A system similar to the German numbers system is used for other numbers between 20 and above : 21 is {{lang|acw|واحد و عشرين}} {{IPA|/waːħid u ʕiʃriːn/}} which literally mean ('one and twenty') and 485 is {{lang|acw|أربعمية و خمسة و ثمانين}} {{IPA|/urbuʕmijːa u xamsa u tamaːniːn/}} which literally mean ('four hundred and five and eighty').
Unlike Classical Arabic, the only number that is gender specific in Hejazi is "one" which has two forms {{lang|acw|واحد}} ''m.'' and {{lang|acw|وحدة}} ''f.'' as in {{lang|acw|كتاب واحد}} {{IPA|/kitaːb waːħid/}} ('one book') or {{lang|acw|سيارة وحدة}} {{IPA|/sajːaːra waħda/}} ('one car'), with {{lang|acw|كتاب}} being a masculine noun and {{lang|acw|سيّارة}} a feminine noun.
* for 2 as in 'two cars' 'two years' 'two houses' etc. the dual form is used instead of the number with the suffix ēn {{IPA|/eːn/}} or tēn {{IPA|/teːn/}} (if the noun ends with a feminine {{IPA|/a/}}) as in {{lang|acw|كتابين}} {{IPA|/kitaːb'''eːn'''/}} ('two books') or {{lang|acw|سيّارتين}} {{IPA|/sajːara'''teːn'''/}} ('two cars'), for emphasis they can be said as {{lang|acw|كتابين اثنين}} or {{lang|acw|سيّارتين اثنين}}. * for numbers 3 to 10 the noun following the number is in plural form as in {{lang|acw|اربعة كتب}} {{IPA|/arbaʕa kutub/}} ('4 books') or {{lang|acw|عشرة سيّارات}} {{IPA|/ʕaʃara sajːaːraːt/}} ('10 cars'). * for numbers 11 and above the noun following the number is in singular form as in :- ** from 11 to 19 an {{lang|acw|ـر}} [ar] is added to the end of the numbers as in {{lang|acw|اربعطعشر كتاب}} {{IPA|/arbaʕtˤaʕʃ'''ar''' kitaːb/}} ('14 books') or {{lang|acw|احدعشر سيّارة}} {{IPA|/iħdaʕʃ'''ar''' sajːaːra/}} ('11 cars'). ** for 100s a [t] is added to the end of the numbers before the counted nouns as in {{lang|acw|ثلثميّة سيّارة}} {{IPA|/tultumijːa'''t''' sajːaːra/}} ('300 cars'). ** other numbers are simply added to the singular form of the noun {{lang|acw|واحد و عشرين كتاب}} {{IPA|/waːħid u ʕiʃriːn kitaːb/}} ('21 books').
== Grammar == === Subject pronouns === In Hejazi Arabic, [[personal pronoun]]s have eight forms. In singular, the 2nd and 3rd persons differentiate gender, while the 1st person and plural do not. {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Subject pronouns ! colspan="2" | Person ! Singular ! Plural |- ! colspan="2" | 1st | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ana}} ''انا'' '' | colspan=2 style="text-align: left;"|''{{transl|ar|ALA|iħna}} ''احنا'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 2nd ! <small>masculine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|inta}} ''َانت'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|intu}} ''انتو'' '' |- ! <small>feminine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|inti}} ''ِانتي''/''انت'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 3rd ! <small>masculine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|huwwa}} ''هو'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|humma}} ''همَّ'' '' |- ! <small>feminine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|hiyya}} ''هي'' '' |}
{{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Negative subject pronouns ! colspan="2" | Person ! Singular ! Plural |- ! colspan="2" | 1st | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|mani}} ''مني'' '' | colspan=2 style="text-align: center;"|''{{transl|ar|ALA|maħna}} ''محنا'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 2nd ! <small>masculine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|manta}} ''َمنت'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|mantu}} ''منتو'' '' |- ! <small>feminine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|manti}} ''ِمنتي''/''منت'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 3rd ! <small>masculine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|mahu}} ''مهو'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|mahum}} ''مهم'' '' |- ! <small>feminine</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|mahi}} ''مهي'' '' |} {{col-end}}
=== Verbs === Hejazi Arabic verbs, as with the verbs in other [[Semitic languages]], and the entire vocabulary in those languages, are based on a set of three, four also five consonants (but mainly three consonants) called a [[Semitic root|root]] (''triliteral'' or ''quadriliteral'' according to the number of consonants). The root communicates the basic meaning of the verb, e.g. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|k-t-b}}'' 'to write', ''{{transl|ar|ALA|ʼ-k-l}}'' 'to eat'. Changes to the vowels in between the consonants, along with prefixes or suffixes, specify grammatical functions such as : * Two tenses ('''past''', '''present'''; present progressive is indicated by the prefix (b-), future is indicated by the prefix (ħ-)) * Two voices (active, passive) * Two genders (masculine, feminine) * Three persons (first, second, third) * Two numbers (singular, plural) * Two moods (indicative, imperative). Hejazi Has a single indicative present verb mood instead of the three Classical Arabic present verb moods (indicative رفع, subjunctive نصب, jussive {{lang|acw|جزم}}), it also includes present progressive tense which was not part of the Classical Arabic grammar, and has a two grammatical number in verbs (Singular and Plural) instead of the Classical (Singular, Dual and Plural).
==== Regular verbs ==== The most common verbs in Hejazi have a given vowel pattern for past ('''a''' and '''i''') to present ('''a''' or '''u''' or '''i'''). Combinations of each exist:
{| class="wikitable centered" style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" | Vowel patterns ! rowspan="2" | Example |- ! Past ! Present |- | a | a | raħ'''a'''m {{lang|acw|رحم}} ''he forgave'' – yirħ'''a'''m {{lang|acw|يرحم}} ''he forgives'' |- | a | u | ḍar'''a'''b {{lang|acw|ضرب}} ''he hit'' – yiḍr'''u'''b {{lang|acw|يضرب}} ''he hits'' |- | a | i | ġas'''a'''l {{lang|acw|غسل}} ''he washed'' – yiġs'''i'''l {{lang|acw|يغسل}} ''he washes'' |- | i | a | fih'''i'''m {{lang|acw|فهم}} ''he understood'' – yifh'''a'''m {{lang|acw|يفهم}} ''he understands'' |- | i | i | ʕir'''i'''f {{lang|acw|عرف}} ''he knew'' – yiʕr'''i'''f {{lang|acw|يعرف}} ''he knows'' |}
According to Arab grammarians, verbs are divided into '''three''' categories; Past ماضي, Present {{lang|acw|مضارع}} and Imperative {{lang|acw|أمر}}. An example from the root ''{{transl|ar|ALA|k-t-b}}'' the verb ''katab'''t'''/'''<big>ʼ</big>a'''ktub'' 'i wrote/i write' (which is a regular sound verb):
{| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" | Tense/Mood ! colspan="2" | Past "wrote" ! colspan="2" | Present (Indicative) "write" ! colspan="2" | Imperative "write!" |- ! colspan="2" | Person ! Singular ! Plural ! Singular ! Plural ! Singular ! Plural |- ! colspan="2" | 1st | {{lang|acw|كتبت}} ''(katab)-t'' | {{lang|acw|كتبنا}} ''(katab)-na'' | {{lang|acw|أكتب}} <big>ʼ</big>''a-(ktub)'' | {{lang|acw|نكتب}} ''ni-(ktub)'' | colspan="2" | |- ! rowspan="2" | 2nd ! <small>masculine</small> | {{lang|acw|كتبت}} ''(katab)-t'' | rowspan="2" | كتبتوا ''(katab)-tu'' | {{lang|acw|تكتب}} ''ti-(ktub)'' | rowspan="2" | تكتبوا ''ti-(ktub)-u'' | {{lang|acw|أكتب}} ''[a]-(ktub)'' | rowspan="2" | {{lang|acw|أكتبوا}} ''[a]-(ktub)-u'' |- ! <small>feminine</small> | {{lang|acw|كتبتي}} ''(katab)-ti'' | {{lang|acw|تكتبي}} ''ti-(ktub)-i'' | {{lang|acw|أكتبي}} ''[a]-(ktub)-i'' |- ! rowspan="2" | 3rd ! <small>masculine</small> | style="background:silver" | {{lang|acw|كتب}} ''(katab)'' | rowspan="2" style="background:silver" | كتبوا ''(katab)-u'' | {{lang|acw|يكتب}} ''yi-(ktub)'' | rowspan="2" | يكتبوا ''yi-(ktub)-u'' | rowspan=2 colspan="2" | |- ! <small>feminine</small> | style="background:silver" | {{lang|acw|كتبت}} ''(katab)-at'' | {{lang|acw|تكتب}} ''ti-(ktub)'' |} While present progressive and future are indicated by adding the prefix (b-) and (ħ-) respectively to the present (indicative) : {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" | Tense/Mood ! colspan="2" | Present Progressive "writing" ! colspan="2" | Future "will write" |- ! colspan="2" | Person ! Singular ! Plural ! Singular ! Plural |- ! colspan="2" | 1st | {{lang|acw|بكتب}} or {{lang|acw|بأكتب}} '''''ba'''-a-(ktub)'' | {{lang|acw|بنكتب}} '''''bi'''-ni-(ktub)'' | {{lang|acw|حكتب}} or {{lang|acw|حأكتب}} '''''ħa'''-a-(ktub)'' | {{lang|acw|حنكتب}} '''''ħa'''-ni-(ktub)'' |- ! rowspan="2" | 2nd ! <small>masculine</small> | {{lang|acw|بتكتب}} '''''bi'''-ti-(ktub)'' | rowspan="2" | بتكتبوا '''''bi'''-ti-(ktub)-u'' | {{lang|acw|حتكتب}} '''''ħa'''-ti-(ktub)'' | rowspan="2" | حتكتبوا '''''ħa'''-ti-(ktub)-u'' |- ! <small>feminine</small> | {{lang|acw|بتكتبي}} '''''bi'''-ti-(ktub)-i'' | {{lang|acw|حتكتبي}} '''''ħa'''-ti-(ktub)-i'' |- ! rowspan="2" | 3rd ! <small>masculine</small> | {{lang|acw|بيكتب}} '''''bi'''-yi-(ktub)'' | rowspan="2" | بيكتبوا '''''bi'''-yi-(ktub)-u'' | {{lang|acw|حيكتب}} '''''ħa'''-yi-(ktub)'' | rowspan="2" | حيكتبوا '''''ħa'''-yi-(ktub)-u'' |- ! <small>feminine</small> | {{lang|acw|بتكتب}} '''''bi'''-ti-(ktub)'' | {{lang|acw|حتكتب}} '''''ħa'''-ti-(ktub)'' |} * The Active Participles {{lang|acw|قاعد}} {{IPA|/gaːʕid/}}, {{lang|acw|قاعدة}} {{IPA|/gaːʕda/}} and {{lang|acw|قاعدين}} {{IPA|/gaːʕdiːn/}} can be used instead of the prefix {{lang|acw|بـ}} [b-] as in {{lang|acw|قاعد اكتب}} {{IPA|/gaːʕid aktub/}} ('i'm writing') instead of بأكتب/ بكتب {{IPA|/baktub/}} / {{IPA|/baʔaktub/}} ('i'm writing') without any change in the meaning. * when an indirect object pronoun (لي ,لها ,لهم...etc) is added to a present verb or a masculine singular imperative verb that has a long vowel in the last syllable as in {{lang|acw|أعيد}} {{IPA|/ʔaʕiːd/}} ('I repeat') or {{lang|acw|قول}} {{IPA|/guːl/}} ('say!'); the vowel is shortened before the suffixes as in {{lang|acw|أعِد لك}} {{IPA|/ʔaʕidlak/}} ('I repeat for you') and {{lang|acw|قُل لها}} {{IPA|/gulːaha/}} ('tell her!') with the verbs resembling the [[Arabic verbs|Jussive mood conjugation]] in Classical Arabic * the 3rd person past plural suffix -/u/ turns into -/oː/ (long o) before pronouns. as in {{lang|ar|كتبوا}} {{IPA|/katab'''u'''/}} ('they wrote') → {{lang|ar|كتبوا لي}} {{IPA|/katab'''oː'''li/}} ('they wrote to me'), and {{lang|ar|عرفوا}} {{IPA|/ʕirf'''u'''/}} ('they knew') → {{lang|ar|عرفوني}} {{IPA|/ʕirf'''oː'''ni/}} ('they knew me') * the verbs highlighted in silver sometimes come in irregular forms e.g. (ħabbē)-t "i loved", (ħabbē)-na "we loved" but (ħabb) "he loved" and (ħabb)-u "they loved".
Example: '''katabt/aktub''' "write": non-finite forms
{| class="wikitable" ! Number/Gender ! {{lang|acw|اسم الفاعل}} Active Participle ! {{lang|acw|اسم المفعول}} Passive Participle ! {{lang|acw|مصدر}} Verbal Noun |- ! Masc. Sg. | ''kātib'' كاتب | ''maktūb'' مكتوب | rowspan="3" | ''kitāba'' كتابة |- ! Fem. Sg. | ''kātb-a'' كاتبة | ''maktūb-a'' مكتوبة |- ! Pl. | ''kātb-īn'' كاتبين | ''maktūb-īn'' مكتوبين |}
Active participles act as adjectives, and so they must agree with their subject. An active participle can be used in several ways: # to describe a state of being (understanding; knowing). # to describe what someone is doing right now (going, leaving) as in some verbs like {{lang|acw|رحت}} ("i went") the active participle {{lang|acw|رايح}} ("i'm going") is used instead of present continuous form to give the same meaning of an ongoing action. # to indicate that someone/something is in a state of having done something (having put something somewhere, having lived somewhere for a period of time).
=== Object pronouns === [[Enclitic]] forms of object pronouns are suffixes that are affixed to various parts of speech, with varying meanings: * To the [[construct state]] of nouns, where they have the meaning of possessive demonstratives, e.g. "my, your, his". * To verbs, where they have the meaning of direct object pronouns, e.g. "me, you, him". * To verbs, where they have the meaning of indirect object pronouns, e.g. "(to/for) me,(to/for) you, (to/for) him". * To prepositions. Unlike [[Egyptian Arabic]], in Hejazi no more than one pronoun can be suffixed to a word.
{{col-begin}} {{col-3}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Possessive Pronouns (nominal)<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Omar|1975}}</ref> ! colspan="2" | Person ! Singular ! Plural |- ! colspan="2" | 1st | style=background:silver| ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-i/(-ya/-yya){{ref|12|2}} my}} ''ـي'' '' | colspan=2 style="text-align: center;"|''{{transl|ar|ALA|-na our}} ''ـنا'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 2nd ! <small>masculine m.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-ak/(-k) your}} ''ـك'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-kum your}} ''ـكم'' '' |- ! <small>feminine f.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-ik/(-ki) your}} ''ـكي)/ـك)'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 3rd ! <small>masculine m.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-uʰ/( -[ː]ʰ {{ref|11|1}}) his}} ''ـه'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-hum their}} ''ـهم'' '' |- ! <small>feminine f.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-ha her}} ''ـها'' '' |}

{| class="wikitable" |+ Indirect Object Pronouns (verbal) ! colspan="2" | Person ! Singular ! Plural |- ! colspan="2" | 1st | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-li (for/to) me}} ''لي'' '' | colspan=2 style="text-align: center;"|''{{transl|ar|ALA|-lana us}} ''لنا'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 2nd ! <small>masculine m.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-lak you}} ''لَك'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-lakum you}} ''لكم'' '' |- ! <small>feminine f.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-lik you}} ''لِك'' '' |- ! rowspan="2" | 3rd ! <small>masculine m.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-luʰ him}} ''له'' '' | rowspan="2" | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-lahum them}} ''لهم'' '' |- ! <small>feminine f.</small> | ''{{transl|ar|ALA|-laha her}} ''لها'' '' |} {{col-end}}
Modifications:- * When a noun ends in a feminine {{IPA|/a/}} vowel as in {{lang|acw|مدرسة}} {{IPA|/madrasa/}} ('school') : a {{IPA|/t/}} is added before the suffixes as in → {{lang|acw|مدرستي}} {{IPA|/madrasa'''t'''i/}} ('my school'), {{lang|acw|مدرسته}} {{IPA|/madrasa'''t'''u/}} ('his school'), {{lang|acw|مدرستها}} {{IPA|/madrasa'''t'''ha/}} ('her school') and so on. * After a word ends in a vowel (other than the {{IPA|/-a/}} of the feminine nouns), the vowel is lengthened, and the pronouns in (Parentheses) are used instead of their original counterparts :- ** the possessive pronouns as in {{lang|acw|كرسي}} {{IPA|/kursi/}} ('chair') → {{lang|acw|كرسيه}} {{IPA|/kurs'''iː'''/}} ('his chair'), {{lang|acw|كرسينا}} {{IPA|/kurs'''iː'''na/}} ('our chair'), {{lang|acw|كرسيكي}} {{IPA|/kurs'''iːki'''/}} ('your chair' f.) ** the direct object pronouns {{lang|acw|لاحقنا}} {{IPA|/laːħagna/}} ('we followed') → {{lang|acw|لاحقناه}} {{IPA|/laːħagn'''aː'''/}} ('we followed him'), {{lang|acw|لاحقناكي}} {{IPA|/laːħagn'''aː'''ki/}} ('we followed you' feminine). ** the indirect object pronouns {{lang|acw|رحنا}} {{IPA|/ruħna/}} ('we went') → {{lang|acw|رحنا له}} {{IPA|/ruħn'''aː'''lu/}} ('we went to him'). * After a word that ends in two consonants, or which has a long vowel in the last syllable, {{IPA|/-a-/}} is inserted before the 5 suffixes which begin with a consonant {{IPA|/-ni/}}, {{IPA|/-na/}}, {{IPA|/-ha/}}, {{IPA|/-hom/}}, {{IPA|/-kom/}}. ** the possessive pronouns {{lang|acw|كتاب}} {{IPA|/kitaːb/}} ('book') → {{lang|acw|كتابها}} {{IPA|/kitaːb'''a'''ha/}} ('her book'), {{lang|acw|كتابهم}} {{IPA|/kitaːb'''a'''hum/}} ('their book'), {{lang|acw|كتابكم}} {{IPA|/kitaːb'''a'''kum/}} ('your book' plural), {{lang|acw|كتابنا}} {{IPA|/kitaːb'''a'''na/}} ('our book'). ** the direct object pronouns {{lang|acw|عرفت}} {{IPA|/ʕirift/}} ('you knew') → {{lang|acw|عرفتني}} {{IPA|/ʕirift'''a'''ni/}} ('you knew me'), {{lang|acw|عرفتنا}} {{IPA|/ʕirift'''a'''na/}} ('you knew us'), {{lang|acw|عرفتها}} {{IPA|/ʕirift'''a'''ha/}} ('you knew her'), {{lang|acw|عرفتهم}} {{IPA|/ʕirift'''a'''hum/}} ('you knew them'). * '''only''' with indirect object pronouns when a verb ends in two consonants as in katabt {{lang|acw|كتبت}} {{IPA|/katabt/}} ('i wrote') : an {{IPA|/-al-/}} is added before the Indirect object pronoun suffixes → katabtallu {{lang|acw|كتبت له}} {{IPA|/katabt'''al'''ːu/}} ('i wrote to him'), katabtallahum {{lang|acw|كتبت لهم}} {{IPA|/katabt'''al'''ːahum/}} ('i wrote to them'). * '''only''' with indirect object pronouns when a verb has a long vowel in the last syllable as in {{lang|acw|أروح}} {{IPA|/aruːħ/}} ('I go') : the vowel is shortened before the suffixes → {{lang|acw|أرُح لها}} {{IPA|/aruħlaha/}} ('I go to her') with the verbs resembling the Jussive mood conjugation in written Classical Arabic. * {{note|11|1}} the colon between the (Parentheses) indicate that only the vowel is lengthened, since the word-final {{lang|acw|ـه}} [h] is silent in this position. * {{note|12|2}} if a noun ends with a vowel (other than the {{IPA|/-a/}} of the feminine nouns) that is {{IPA|/u/}} or {{IPA|/a/}} then the suffix (-ya) is used as in {{lang|acw|أبو}} {{IPA|/abu/}} ('father') becomes {{lang|acw|َابوي}} {{IPA|/abuːja/}} ('my father') but if it ends with an {{IPA|/i/}} then the suffix (-yya) is added as in {{lang|acw|َّكرسي}} {{IPA|/kursijːa/}} ('my chair'). * it is uncommon for Hejazi nouns to end in a vowel other than the {{IPA|/-a/}} of the feminine nouns.
== Writing system == [[File:Qur'anic Manuscript - 2 - Hijazi script.jpg|thumb|right|An Early Qur'anic manuscript written in [[Hijazi script]] (8th century AD)|290x290px]] Hejazi is written using the [[Arabic alphabet]]; like other [[varieties of Arabic]], Hejazi does not have a standard form of writing and mostly follows Classical Arabic rules of writing.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Modern Arabic: Structures, Functions, and Varieties|last = Holes|first = Clive|publisher = Georgetown University Press, Washington D.C.|year = 2004|isbn = |location = Washington D.C.|pages = 92}}</ref> In general people alternate between writing the words according to their etymology or the phoneme used while pronouncing them, which mainly has an effect on the three letters {{angbr|[[Ṯāʾ|ث]]}} {{angbr|[[Ḏāl|ذ]]}} and {{angbr|[[Ẓāʾ|ظ]]}}, for example writing {{lang|acw|تخين}} instead of {{lang|acw|ثخين}} or {{lang|acw|ديل}} instead of {{lang|acw|ذيل}} although this alternation in writing is not considered acceptable by all Hejazi speakers.
Another alternation which is more likely to appear happens when writing words that end in a short vowel {{IPA|/a, u, i/}}, the writer would choose whether to add a vowel letter {{angbr|و}} {{angbr|ا}} or {{angbr|ي}} at the end of the word as in {{lang|acw|انتي}} {{IPA|/inti/}} ('you' singular feminine) to differentiate it from {{lang|acw|انت}} {{IPA|/inta/}} ('you' singular masculine), or use the Classical form {{lang|acw|انت}} which can be pronounced {{IPA|/inta/}} or {{IPA|/inti/}}, this happens since most word-final short vowels from the Classical Arabic period have been omitted and most word-final unstressed long vowel letters have been shortened in Hejazi. In Arabic handwriting of everyday use, in general publications, and on street signs, short vowels are typically not written, and when needed to be written they are written in a form of [[Arabic diacritics|diacritics]]; <big>{{lang|acw|ـَ}}</big> above the letter for {{IPA|/a/}}, <big>{{lang|acw|ـُ}}</big> above the letter for {{IPA|/u/}}, <big>{{lang|ar|ـِ}}</big> under the letter for {{IPA|/i/}}.
The table below shows the Arabic alphabet letters and their corresponding phonemes in Hejazi:
{| class="wikitable" ! Letter !! colspan="2" | Phonemes (IPA) !! Example !! Pronunciation |- ! rowspan="4" | '''[[ا]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|ʔ}} (see {{angbr|ء}} [[Hamza]]). || {{lang|acw|سأل}} "he asked" || {{IPA|/saʔal/}} |- | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|aː}} || {{lang|acw|باب}} "door" || {{IPA|/baːb/}} |- | colspan="2" |{{IPAslink|a}} only when word-final and unstressed (when word-final and stressed it's an {{IPAslink|aː}}) |{{lang|acw|شُفنا}} "we saw", (ذا ''m.'' "this") |{{IPA|/ˈʃufna/}}, (/ˈdaː/ or /ˈðaː/) |- | colspan="2" |additional ∅ silent word-final only in plural verbs and after [[nunation]] |{{lang|acw|قالوا}} "they said", {{lang|acw|شكرًا}} "thanks" |{{IPA|/gaːlu/}}, {{IPA|/ʃukran/}} |- ! '''[[ح]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|ħ}} || {{lang|acw|حوش}} "courtyard" || {{IPA|/ħoːʃ/}} |- ! '''[[خ]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|x}} || {{lang|acw|خرقة}} "rag" || {{IPA|/xirga/}} |- ! '''[[د]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|d}} || {{lang|acw|دولاب}} "closet" || {{IPA|/doːˈlaːb/}} |- style="text-align:center;" | rowspan="3" style="background:silver" | '''[[ذ]]''' |- | either {{IPAslink|d}}, merging with {{angbr|د}} | rowspan="2" |or always/in some words as {{IPAslink|ð}}|| {{lang|acw|ذيل}} "tail" || {{IPA|/deːl/}} or {{IPA|/ðeːl/}} |- | or {{IPAslink|z}}, merging with {{angbr|ز}}||{{lang|acw|ذوق}} "taste" || {{IPA|/zoːg/}} or {{IPA|/ðoːg/}} |- ! '''[[ر]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|r}} || {{lang|acw|رمل}} "sand" || {{IPA|/ramil/}} |- ! '''[[ز]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|z}} || {{lang|acw|زحليقة}} "slide" || {{IPA|/zuħleːga/}} |- ! '''[[س]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|s}} || {{lang|acw|سمكة}} "fish" || {{IPA|/samaka/}} |- ! '''[[ش]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|ʃ}} || {{lang|acw|شيول}} "loader" || {{IPA|/ʃeːwal/}} |- ! '''[[ص]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|sˤ}} || {{lang|acw|صُفِّيرة}} "whistle" || {{IPA|/sˁuˈfːeːra/}} |- ! '''[[ض]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|dˤ}} || {{lang|acw|ضرس}} "molar" || {{IPA|/dˤirs/}} |- ! '''[[ط]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|tˤ}} || {{lang|acw|طرقة}} "corridor" || {{IPA|/tˤurga/}} |- style="text-align:center;" | rowspan="3" style="background:silver" | '''[[ظ]]''' |- | either {{IPAslink|dˤ}}, merging with {{angbr|ض}} | rowspan="2" |or always/in some words as {{IPA|[ðˤ]}}||{{lang|acw|ظل}} "shade" ||{{IPA|/dˤilː/}} or {{IPA|[ðˤɪlː]}} |- | or {{IPAslink|zˤ}} (distinct phoneme)||{{lang|acw|لحظة}} "moment" ||{{IPA|/laħzˤa/}} or {{IPA|[laħðˤa]}} |- ! '''[[ع]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|ʕ}} || {{lang|acw|عين}} "eye" || {{IPA|/ʕeːn/}} |- ! '''[[غ]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|ɣ}} || {{lang|acw|غراب}} "crow" || {{IPA|/ɣuraːb/}} |- ! '''[[ف]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|f}} || {{lang|acw|فم}} "mouth" || {{IPA|/famː/}} |- ! '''[[ق]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|g}}||{{lang|acw|قلب}} "heart" | | {{IPA|/galb/}} |- ! '''[[ك]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|k}} || {{lang|acw|كلب}} "dog" || {{IPA|/kalb/}} |- ! '''[[ل]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|l}} (marginal phoneme {{IPAslink|ɫ}} only in the word {{lang|acw|الله}} and words derived from it) ||{{lang|acw|لحم}} "meat", ({{lang|acw|الله}} "god") || {{IPA|/laħam/}}, ({{IPA|/aɫːaːh/}}) |- ! '''[[م]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|m}} || {{lang|acw|موية}} "water" || {{IPA|/moːja/}} |- ! '''[[ن]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|n}} || {{lang|acw|ناس}} "people" || {{IPA|/naːs/}} |- ! '''[[هـ]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|h}} (silent when word-final in '''3rd''' '''person''' '''masculine singular''' '''pronouns''' and some words) ||{{lang|acw|هوا|هوا}} "air", ({{lang|acw|كتابُه}} "'''his''' book", {{lang|acw|شفناه}} "we saw '''him'''") || {{IPA|/hawa/}}, ({{IPA|/kitaːbu/}}, {{IPA|/ʃufˈnaː/}}) |- ! rowspan="4" | '''[[و]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|w}} || {{lang|acw|وردة}} "rose" || {{IPA|/warda/}} |- | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|uː}} || {{lang|acw|فوق}} "wake up!" || {{IPA|/fuːg/}} |- | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|o̞ː|oː}} || {{lang|acw|فوق}} "above, up" || {{IPA|/foːg/}} |- | colspan="2" |{{IPAslink|u}} only when word-final and unstressed (when word-final and stressed it's either {{IPAslink|uː}} or {{IPAslink|o̞ː|oː}}) |{{lang|acw|ربو}} "asthma", ({{lang|acw|مو}} "is not", {{lang|acw|جوا}} "they came") |{{IPA|/ˈrabu/}}, ({{IPA|/ˈmuː/}}, {{IPA|/ˈd͡ʒoː/}}) |- ! rowspan="4" | '''[[ي]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|j}} || {{lang|acw|يد}} "hand" || {{IPA|/jadː/}} |- | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|iː}} || {{lang|acw|بيض}} "whites ''pl.''" || {{IPA|/biːdˤ/}} |- | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|e̞ː|eː}} || {{lang|acw|بيض}} "eggs" || {{IPA|/beːdˤ/}} |- | colspan="2" |{{IPAslink|i}} only when word-final and unstressed (when word-final and stressed it's either {{IPAslink|iː}} or {{IPAslink|e̞ː|eː}}) |{{lang|acw|سعودي}} "saudi", ({{lang|acw|ذي}} ''f.'' "this") |{{IPA|/suˈʕuːdi/}}, ({{IPA|/ˈdiː/}} or {{IPA|/ˈðiː/}}) |- ! colspan="5" | Additional non-native letters |- ! '''[[Pe (Persian letter)|پ]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|p}} (can be written and/or pronounced as a {{angbr|[[ب]]}} depending on the speaker) | {{lang|acw|پول ~ بول}} "Paul" | {{IPA|/poːl/}} ~ {{IPA|/boːl/}} |- ! '''[[Ve (Arabic letter)|ڤ]]''' | colspan="2" | {{IPAslink|v}} (can be written and/or pronounced as a {{angbr|[[Fa'|ف]]}} depending on the speaker) | {{lang|acw|ڤيروس ~ فيروس}} "virus" | {{IPA|/vajruːs/}} ~ {{IPA|/fajruːs/}} |}
Notes:
* The classical {{IPAblink|q}} is an [[allophone]] for {{IPA|/g/}} {{angbr|[[Qoph|ق]]}} only in few words and phrases e.g. {{lang|acw|قاموس}} "dictionary" {{IPA|/gaːmuːs/}} pronounced {{IPA|[qaːmuːs]}}. *{{IPA|/zˤ/}} is spelled {{angbr|[[Ḍād|ض]]}} only in a number of words from the two [[Semitic root|trilateral roots]] {{angbr|ض ب ط}} and {{angbr|ض ر ط}}, as in {{lang|acw|ضبط}} ("it worked") pronounced {{IPA|/zˤabatˤ/}} and not {{IPA|/dˤabatˤ/}}. * {{angbr|[[ة]]}} is only used at the end of words and mainly to mark [[Grammatical gender|femi]]<nowiki/>[[Grammatical gender|nine gender]] for [[noun]]s and [[adjective]]<nowiki/>[[adjective|<nowiki/>]]s with few exceptions (e.g. {{lang|ar|أسامة}}; a male noun). phonemically It is silent, except when in [[construct state]] it is a /t/, which leads to the word-final /-at/. e.g. {{lang|ar|رسالة}} {{IPA|/risaːl'''a'''/}} 'message' → {{lang|ar|رسالة أحمد}} {{IPA|/risaːl'''at''' ʔaħmad/}} 'Ahmad's message'. *{{angbr|[[هـ]]}} {{IPAslink|h}} is silent only word-final in some words and in '''3rd''' '''person''' '''masculine singular''' '''pronoun''', as in the [[Heteronym (linguistics)|heteronym]] {{lang|ar|ليه}} pronounced lē {{IPA|/leː/}} 'why?' or lī {{IPA|/liː/}} 'for '''him'''<nowiki/>' although the {{IPAslink|h}} can be added for emphasis, the silent {{angbr|[[هـ]]}} also helps in distinguishing [[minimal pair]]s with word-final vowe<nowiki/>l length contrast {{lang|ar|تبغي}} tibḡ'''i''' {{IPA|/tibɣ'''i'''/}} 'you <nowiki/>want ''f.''<nowiki/>' vs. {{lang|ar|تبغيه}} tibḡ'''ī''' {{IPA|/tibɣ'''iː'''/}} 'you want '''him''' ''f.''<nowiki/>'. * Short vowels are written as [[Arabic diacritics|diacritics]] :- *# <big>{{lang|acw|ـَ}}</big> above the letter for {{IPA|/a/}}. *# <big>{{lang|acw|ـُ}}</big> above the letter for {{IPA|/u/}}. *# <big>{{lang|ar|ـِ}}</big> under the letter for {{IPA|/i/}}.
== Rural dialects == The varieties of Arabic spoken in the smaller towns and by the bedouin tribes in the Hejaz region are relatively under-studied. However, the speech of some tribes shows much closer affinity to other bedouin dialects, particularly those of neighboring [[Najd]], than to those of the urban Hejazi cities. The dialects of northern Hejazi tribes [[Dialect continuum|merge]] into those of [[Jordan]] and [[Sinai]], while the dialects in the south [[Dialect continuum|merge]] with those of [['Asir]] and [[Najd]]. Also, not all speakers of these bedouin dialects are figuratively [[nomadic]] bedouins; some are simply sedentary sections that live in rural areas, and thus speak dialects similar to those of their bedouin neighbors.
=== Al-`Ula === The dialect of [[Al-`Ula]] governorate in the northern part of the [[Al Madinah Region|Madinah region]]. Although understudied, it is considered to be unique among the Hejazi dialects, it is known for its pronunciation of Classical Arabic {{angbr|[[Kaph|ك]]}} {{IPA|/k/}} as a {{angbr|[[Shin (letter)|ش]]}} {{IPA|/[[Voiceless palato-alveolar sibilant|ʃ]]/}} (e.g. {{lang|ar|تكذب}} {{IPA|/takðib/}} becomes {{lang|ar|تشذب}} {{IPA|/taʃðib/}}), the dialect also shows a tendency to pronounce long {{IPA|/aː/}} as {{IPAblink|e|eː}} (e.g. Classical {{lang|ar|ماء}} {{IPA|/maːʔ/}} becomes {{lang|ar|ميء}} [meːʔ]), in some instances the Classical {{IPA|/q/}} becomes a {{IPAslink|d͡ʒ}} as in {{lang|ar|قايلة}} {{IPA|/qaːjla/}} becomes {{lang|ar|جايلة}} {{IPA|/d͡ʒaːjla/}}, also the second person singular feminine pronoun {{IPA|/ik/}} tends to be pronounced as /i[[Voiceless palato-alveolar sibilant|ʃ]]/ (e.g. {{lang|ar|رجلك}} {{IPA|/rid͡ʒlik/}} ('your foot') becomes {{lang|ar|رجلش}} {{IPA|/rid͡ʒliʃ/}}.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.al-jazirah.com/2008/20080629/wo5.htm|title=Spoken Al-'Ula dialect between privacy and fears of extinction. (in Arabic)|last=Aljuhani|first=Sultan|date=2008|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
=== Badr === The dialect of [[Badr, Saudi Arabia|Badr]] governorate in the western part of the [[Al Madinah Region|Madinah region]] is mainly noted for its lengthening of word-final syllables and its alternative pronunciation of some phonemes as in {{lang|ar|سؤال}} {{IPA|/suʔaːl/}} which is pronounced as {{lang|ar|سعال}} {{IPA|/suʕaːl/}}, it also shares some features with the general urban dialect in which modern standard Arabic {{lang|ar|ثلاجة}} {{IPA|/θalːaːd͡ʒa/}} is pronounced {{lang|ar|تلاجة}} {{IPA|/talːaːd͡ʒa/}}, another unique feature of the dialect is its similarity to the Arabic dialects of [[Bahrain]].
==See also== * [[Varieties of Arabic]] * [[Peninsular Arabic]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Portal|Saudi Arabia|Language}} * [[Kees Versteegh]], ''The Arabic Language'', NITLE Arab World Project, by the permission of Edinburgh University Press, [https://web.archive.org/web/20060927155023/http://arabworld.nitle.org/texts.php?module_id=1&reading_id=113&sequence=1] * {{cite journal |title = Some Characteristics of Meccan Speech |last = Ingham |first = Bruce |journal = [[Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London]] |publisher = [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] |issn = 1474-0699 |volume = 34 |issue = 2 |year = 1971 |pages = 273–97 |jstor = 612692 |via = [[JSTOR]] |registration = y }}

E. | year=2002 | title=The Phonology and Morphology of Arabic | ref=harv | url=http://www.kamal-osman.com/wp-content/uploads/The-Phonolgy-and-Morphology-of-Arabic-watson.pdf }} {{Refend}}
